channel.title: Working project for high-efficiency RSC server in C
channel.description:
Hello,
For the last week or so I have put together a working(in the sense that you can login and equip/dequip items, look at objects, and kind of walk) RuneScape Classic server in C. I am running into some troubles with designing the player position packet(I redid much of the client, including reconstruction of many packets), but this should be resolved soon.
I have based my client off of a non-refactored 202 deob, but it's much more modern and OO-driven now.
This compiles on as many systems as I've tried on, OpenBSD(current development environment), FreeBSD, Linux, Windows, Mac OS X...
I plan on hosting it on my quad-core, 1Gbps line, 5TB/mo bandwidth VPS, once I get a beta out in a month or two(I am a NEET so I have all the time in the world to work on it).
I am here asking what the community(you guys) would be interested in. A fun server with PvP as a priority, such as that one server that shall not be mentioned, or a full replica like RSCEmulation but with more strict replication rules.
Also, please voice your opinions on whether this is a poor investment of my time. I could easily switch this framework over to a RuneScape 2 server, if you collectively feel it isn't worthwhile this late in RSClassic's life.
Any suggestions at all are welcome; I am willing to take this in any direction you guys see fit. I would like to maximize playercount, and that is usually done by giving the players what they want ;)
Feel free to email me or contact me on MSN, email is at bottom of post.
A picture for some amount of evidence that I'm not just blowing smoke up your asses: [img]http://libslack.so/RUNESCAPE.png[/img]
-Aleksandr Dmitrievich Volkov (volkov.aleksandr.dmitrievich@yandex.ru)

The Enforcer:

How do you plan to counteract the quantum planetary deorientation threat found in C? Just use C++.

The Enforcer Sucks <3

item.title: Working project for high-efficiency RSC server in C
item.dc:creator: @Zlacki Zlacki
item.description:
@Zlacki wrote:

Don’t worry, I will not rely on XQuartz for any of the rendering on OS X. I intend on making a native interface for the three major OSes, Mac OS X, Windows, and UNIX-like Xorg-based systems such as Linux, OpenBSD, OpenIndiana(OpenSolaris), FreeBSD and NetBSD.

Read full topic

[quote=“Zlacki, post:59, topic:457965”]Maybe in next 2 days or so I can make a small video of myself loading the client and login screen appearing, me interacting with it. I’ll include a resource usage monitor of the application on the side in the video. I’ll have a slight bit of C code in background for sake of appearance.
This’ll be after I port to OS X native as I don’t want to use XQuartz much and I already installed Mac OS X Snow Leopard 10.6.8[/quote]

Looking forward to it
dont use xquartz tho
i’d appriciate if u kept us updated more on the progress of your project
best of luck

item.title: Working project for high-efficiency RSC server in C
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

[quote=“Zlacki, post:57, topic:457965”][quote author=imthenull link=topic=560892.msg4280766#msg4280766 date=1365532877]

open source?

If so, not for a while.
[/quote]> : (
question, why change the cache format?

XZ is more efficient comparing size to CPU time, as it uses LZMA2, which last I’d checked(admittedly about a half year back) is the most efficient lossless compression algorithm for data like this.[/quote]Ok, fair enough i guess.

[quote=“Zlacki, post:57, topic:457965”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=560892.msg4280883#msg4280883 date=1365548627]

What do you mean hardly notice the difference? They are immensely different.

[/quote]
I’m afraid I’m lost on what you two are speaking of. Sorry.[/quote]Someone else posted they couldn’t tell the difference between C and C++, they deleted it though.

It will be interesting to see the client written in C, if/when you decide to open source your code. Can you provide us any media yet?

Read full topic
item.source: Working project for high-efficiency RSC server in C

item.title: Working project for high-efficiency RSC server in C
item.dc:creator: @Zlacki Zlacki
item.description:
@Zlacki wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:54, topic:457965”][quote author=Zlacki link=topic=560892.msg4280761#msg4280761 date=1365532293]

open source?

If so, not for a while.
[/quote]> : (
question, why change the cache format?[/quote]
XZ is more efficient comparing size to CPU time, as it uses LZMA2, which last I’d checked(admittedly about a half year back) is the most efficient lossless compression algorithm for data like this.

[quote=“CodeForFame, post:56, topic:457965”][quote author=imthenull link=topic=560892.msg4280861#msg4280861 date=1365545159]
What do you mean hardly notice the difference? They are immensely different.
[/quote][/quote]
I’m afraid I’m lost on what you two are speaking of. Sorry.

I’ve made significant progress in porting the client to C99 to work with Xorg-based UNIX-like systems. I am next going to be adding rendering on OS X natively to my graphics library, and then Windows. Once that is ready, I can port the rest of the logic over and be done with the client in a good month I’d say.

Read full topic
